newsitem.title: GERMANY: Buba's Welteke says expects EMU to begin on time.
newsitem.headline: Buba's Welteke says expects EMU to begin on time.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Ernst Welteke said on Wednesday that Europe's planned monetary union must begin as scheduled.

"I am of the decided opinion that the European currency union must begin, and that this must occur on January 1, 1999," Welteke said in the text of a speech prepared for delivery at a commemorative ceremony at the state central bank in Hesse, where he is president.
A copy of the speech was made available beforehand.

Welteke, a vocal supporter of a timely launch of the currency union, noted that the euro would still have to earn the sense of worth bestowed on the mark. But he added, "The conditions (for monetary union) have been created in such a way that one can say with a certain degree of optimism that the euro will be a good currency."

Talk about the currency union's starting date has dominated the political discussion in Germany in recent months. Germany, considered essential to the success of the project, is having severe difficulties in fulfilling entry requirements.

Separately Welteke explained that although the Bundesbank would hand over its policy-making function to the future European Central Bank once currency union begins, the structure of Germany's nine state central banks would remain largely unchanged.

"Functions excercised by the state central banks will not be changed in fundamental ways," Welteke explained, noting that regional central banks would still be charged with overseeing the transfer of payments, supplying cash, and conducting weekly refinancings.
He added that the presidents of the state central banks would continue to join the Bundesbank president to discuss European monetary policies.

Welteke said that seven regional branch offices have been closed over the last six years and that more closures would follow. This illustrates that "the Bundesbank is in no way an slow moving, clumsy oil tanker but rather in its parts a flexible institution," Welteke said.
